metadata.name: The Way I See It #150
metadata.description:
Abstract artwork that explores imperfect organic-looking shapes and odd forms.

- press 's' to save the PNG image of the current view.
- press 'h' to save 6400x6400 PNG image

Created using p5js.

@VolatileMoods, April, 2022.

metadata.name: Megalopolis #374
metadata.description:
Abstract artwork that generates urban-like structures viewed from the sky.

Options:

- press 'f' to toggle noise filter
- press 's' to save the PNG image of the current view
- press 1, 2, 3, or 4 to save hi-res PNG images

Created using p5js.

@VolatileMoods, May, 2022.

metadata.name: La Playa üèñÔ∏è #29
metadata.description:
A top-down view of a minimalist beach, made with simple geometric shapes and sinusoidal functions. Through a cartoonish style and vivid color palettes, I wanted to represent the feeling of an idyllic summer.

Features:

- 10 Color Palettes 

- 2 Top-down views

Press 's' to export a 2500x2500 PNG file.

Made with p5.js

Seba Ismael, February 2023

metadata.name: APERIODIC #186
metadata.description:
APERIODIC is an exploration of waves in nature

Works can be downloaded in higher resolution by appending the `scale` parameter to the URL. For example: `&scale=1.5`. Default scale is .5

Works can be downloaded as an SVG by pressing the S key.

metadata.name: Absorbed #7
metadata.description:
A collaboration between leading British high-end audio brand KEF, generative artist hieroglyphica, and creative studio Parameta, Absorbed embodies the process of noise becoming high-fidelity sound through KEF‚Äôs Metamaterial Absorption Technology (MAT‚Ñ¢). 

MAT‚Ñ¢ makes the KEF sound what it is: absorbing unwanted distortion to deliver pure, accurate sound exactly as the artist intended. Inspired by this intricacy, Absorbed illustrates pseudorandom networks of patterns, slowly emerging and transforming into the maze-like form of MAT‚Ñ¢. Clarity is revealed, noise is absorbed ‚Äì high-fidelity is found.

The noise fields used in Absorbed are of two distinct types: conventional gradient noise and ‚Äúsinusoidal‚Äù noise, an original algorithm developed for this series. The use of animation as artistic medium reflects the artists‚Äô belief that no single frame can capture the full range of complexity found in the tension between sound and noise, and lets collectors observe for themselves this ever-shifting dialogue. A more extensive discussion of the algorithms used in Absorbed can be found in hieroglyphica‚Äôs companion article on fx(text).

- spacebar will pause and resume the animation
- s will save a still image of the current frame
- technically minded collectors can consult the index.html file for info on how to render and save high-resolution images
- use of hardware acceleration in Chrome may impact performance

Founded by BBC engineer Raymond Cooke in 1961, KEF is a leading British innovator of high-end audio products including HiFi speakers, subwoofers, architectural speakers, wireless speaker-systems, and headphones. Find out more at kef.com or visit our Discord at discord.com/invite/u48Z9yjY2q.

metadata.name: Kinetograms #310
metadata.description:
Each Kinetogram traces the movement of a number of simple shapes constrained within a single cell or a grid of cells. Forces are applied to the shapes in the form of attraction, gravity or shaking.

Some Kinetograms are partially or completely reflected, vertically or horizontally, some with chromatic replacement.

The aspect ratio is 3:4. The palettes are predominantly based on found textile patterns.

Press 's' to save a png image. Press 'e' to redraw and export a 4K png image. Note that drawing and physical simulation takes some time.

For interactive use, press 't' to tilt the board and 'c' to clear the board.

Written in p5.js with 2D physical simulation using Matter.js. Developed in and optimized for Chrome.

metadata.name: Love #282
metadata.description:
We all experience love at different scales, ranging from scarcely perceived instances of kindness to unforgettable affections shown to us by family and friends, pets and partners. Each of these moments link us to the same boundless and enveloping interconnectedness that persists across space and time: the infinite source of our deepest aspirations.

Like the feeling of simple bliss, ‚ÄòLove‚Äô portrays the visceral radiant light and warmth of our innermost joys. By taking a moment to open ourselves up, these swirling worlds of weightless and seemingly infinite brush strokes invite us to slow down and dwell in prismatic intuitive swells.

In doing so, we may find the immense and omnipresent love that needs only our awareness to be felt.

__________

Press 1-9 to load at different scales (1 = 2,000x2,000 (default), 9 = 10,000x10,000)
When zoomed in, once the output is fully loaded, you can click and drag to move around the canvas
Press 'S' to save the image at the current scale
Press 'B' to toggle the background texture on or off
Press 'A' to toggle the loading animation (recommended for very large scales)

Created with p5.js
For third party license information, please see bundle.js.LICENSE.txt
__________
TENDER x teaboswell
May 2022

metadata.name: Blobby #203
metadata.description:
A sphere that has been contorted (or not) in various fashions! 

The spike level indicates how dense the protrusions are and the displacement level indicates how far these protrusions go. If any of those are 0, you'll get a flat sphere.

metadata.name: Richter #74
metadata.description:
Richter is the second collaboration of Richard Nadler and Leander Herzog, following their first project called Gerhard. A generative animation based on multiple layers of color and data, mixed, moved and painted over in realtime. Some fragments stick to the canvas while others get discarded to leave the existing layers visible, allowing a complex surface to emerge and build up over time.
 
Richter works with data from 4 of 24 highres images, 30mb in total. This is the maximum size fxhash allows for a project and three times more than Gerhard. Richard Nadler created stunning new textures, enabling more variation in composition and detail to emerge at much higher resolution. Leander Herzog created the code for the interplay between the layers, motion and interactions. Richter elevates the approach from Gerhard with new methods for the realtime rendering process and new features like offline-first caching. Both artists use different tools and are not aware of the details of each others process, meeting through the interface of pixels as data.
 
Richter is featured in the exhibition "Generative Abstraction" at Expanded.art in Berlin.
 
- Click to start a new layer of motion and color.
- Doubleclick to enter fullscreen.
- Press ‚Äús‚Äù to save the canvas.
- Append ?dpr=4 to the url to increase the resolution.

leanderherzog.ch/2023/richter/
leanderherzog.ch/2022/gerhard/
fxhash.xyz/generative/17030/

metadata.name: Gerhard #63
metadata.description:
Gerhard is a collaboration of Richard Nadler and Leander Herzog on fxhash. A generative animation based on multiple layers of color and data, mixed, moved and painted over in realtime. Some fragments stick to the canvas while others get discarded to leave the existing layers visible, allowing a complex surface to emerge and build up over time. 
Richard Nadler created the textures to control composition and color. Leander Herzog created the code for the interplay between the layers, motion and interactions. Both artists use different tools and are not aware of the details of each others process, meeting through the interface of pixels. This collaboration is enabled by twitter and fxhash, as the generative art community continues to explore abstraction in summer 2022 ‚Äì while extreme temperatures, wildfires, ongoing conflicts and volatile markets continue to escalate. 

- Click to start a new layer of motion and color. 
- Doubleclick to enter fullscreen mode. 
- Press ‚Äús‚Äù to save the current canvas. 
- Append ?dpr=4 to the url to increase the resolution.

https://leanderherzog.ch/2022/gerhard/

metadata.name: September #12
metadata.description:
The Summer Ends
---------------
Controls:
S or double tap (mobile): Download image

A: Toggle loading animation (off by default to improve performance)

1-6: Modify scale (1 = default, 1500 x 2000px, 6 = maximum, 9000 x 12000px (performance intensive, will take a long time to render))
F: Fit to current screen size

T: Toggle grain and texture overlay
H: Toggle shape outlines

B: Cycle border sizes (0 -> 50 -> 75 -> 100 -> 150px)
C: Cycle border colors

I: Cycle visible layers

L: Toggle ‚Äúlive mode‚Äù. This mode will continuously redraw a new output every few seconds using the same base parameters as the original output, but with slight variations.

You can modify the x and y url parameters to set a custom size. Note that the image will change to fit the new size, but overall drawing style, colors, etc. will remain the same.
(For example, for a 1000x2000 image, add &x=1000&y=2000)
---------------
teaboswell 2022
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information
10% of primary sales will be donated to Girls Who Code (https://girlswhocode.com)

metadata.name: Acequia #281
metadata.description:
Acequia (‚Äúah-seh-kee-uh‚Äù) - a Spanish adaptation of the Arabic word as-sƒÅqiya, meaning ‚Äúwater carrier‚Äù. 

In our second collaboration, Rich and Rick are back with our blend of generative code, intricate design, attention to detail, and a splash of charm. 

‚Ä®Acequias are traditional irrigation canals used to distribute rainwater and snowmelt along a complex network of narrow channels. They are found in Spain, the American Southwest, and northern Mexico, where they are essential for sustaining fields, orchards, and gardens in semi-arid regions. ‚Ä®‚Ä®
Our aim in this series is to capture the essence of these waterways in bold geometric designs. Each piece is inspired by a mountain village or town in Andalusia (southern Spain). 

The location determines the cube designs and construction rules that are used to build the final output. These are combined with striking day/night palettes, outline styles, scales, climates, and a few surprises of course!


Controls (in live view): 

- Press [p] to pause water animation 
- Press [e] to complete water animation 
- Press [r] to reset water animation 
- Press [s] to save the current image 
- Press [h] for a high-res output suitable for printing 
- Press [b] to toggle the border

metadata.name: Umbra #118
metadata.description: A generative series of shadows cast by simple geometric shapes.

metadata.name: Deus FX Machina #96
metadata.description:
Inspired by the 1984 Commodore 64 video game, Deus Ex Machina, which follows the story of a defect formed in a machine that grows and evolves until its eventual death.

We are all machines produced by other machines through a unique system of algorithms, all with the potential to go rogue and mutate into something more organic. The conclusion must be that we each have the power to alter our own existence, just as the defect was able to in Deus Ex Machina.

Think of how many people you‚Äôve seen in your life who were born with talents never used because they didn‚Äôt know how, or didn't know that they even existed. It‚Äôs not that they didn‚Äôt have the capacity; it‚Äôs just that their abilities were not the ones chosen by the system.

In this way, we are all machines programmed by a series of algorithms to suit the needs of the construct, keeping us stuck in our box. We have the ability to evolve into something more, but the only way to do this is by taking that first perilous step, risking all to explore beyond its walls.


---------------------


Generative artwork by Sykcolo / @sykcoloart

Royalties: 15% - split:
50% to the original minter
50% to artist (me)

Press '2' to '4' to generate increasingly higher resolutions of the artwork
(will take a while to load, but works)

Press 's' to save a png

Details:

230 hand-picked colour pallets
4 Entity Types
4 Entity Moods
4 Evolution States
3 Types of Defect
2 Bugs

License: MIT

metadata.name: Rainbow Snake #84
metadata.description: Rainbow snakes painting geometric niceties.

metadata.name: Arbour #128
metadata.description:
There is something almost subversive about generative art that mimics nature. Rather than excelling at abstract mathematical beauty, it tries to hold the complexity and elegance of the natural world, all while attempting to be interesting art. This makes it a different kind of challenge than the mathematical attractors and flow fields that are common across generative art.

It may be ironic then that the solution to natural forms is very often mathematical. The trees in this work are built recursively as a graph, much like how one could build a fractal. But chaos is mixed in at each step to allow the shapes to vary, and reduce their self-similarity. This is a different approach to L-systems but the results are very similar.

In this token, there are:
 - Three styles of tree.
 - Twelve colour schemes (six day, six night)
 - Four shapes for leaves.
 - Five leaf patterns
 - And other entropy that cannot be enumerated.

metadata.name: (Dis)ordered loom #123
metadata.description:
"Disordered loom" continues my exploration on texture, points, lines and noise, now in a grid within a grid. With the 'r' key you can toggle between an ordered and disordered loom, the disorder is created by an assigned subset of 4 sets of rotations. With the 't' key you can toggle translation, an additional movement is added/subtracted. With the 'e' key you can toggle more entropy.

You can further self-curate your token by clicking the canvas, colours change with each click, with the 'c' key you can remove a colour, you can press 'c' until two colours remain, with the 'v' key you can reset colours.

With the 'm' key you can mix all possible textures, press 'm' again to switch to your assigned texture. 

With the '+'/'-' keys you can alter the grain, "Disordered loom" implements the p5.grain addon.

Press 'e' to toggle entropy
Press 'r' to toggle between ordered/disordered loom
Press 't' to toggle translation
Press 'm' for mixed textures mode
Press 'c' to remove a color
Press 'v' to reset colors
Press '+'/'-' to alter the grain
Press 's' to save a png image
Press 'j' to save a jpg image
Press 'x' to save a higher resolution png

metadata.name: Circonvolution #83
metadata.description:
Circonvolution is a French word meaning "wrapped around" but also "twists and turns".
In this project, several vortexes drive colors in a chaotic winding path whose final look is sometimes quite organic.

Depending on the computer, the calculation time may be about ten seconds.
---
To save, type:
[1] at 2000x2000 px
To save in high resolution, (can be long)
[2] at 4000x6000 px 
[3] at 6000x6000 px

---

100% done with p5js
Some colors are from "A Dictionary of Color Combinations" by Wada Sanz≈ç
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0.

Herv√© (Jan 23)
